Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. RNA editing, the specific alteration of an RNA molecule relative to the gene from which it was copied, is widespread, and has been most extensively studied in mammals, plants, flies, viruses, and trypanosomes. Observed sequence changes include base conversions, base substitutions, the deletion of encoded nucleotides, and the insertion of additional residues. The only organism known to carry out each of these forms of editing is the primitive eukaryote Physarum polycephalum (Pp). The sequence of virtually all of the mitochondrially-encoded mRNAs, rRNAs, and tRNAs in Pp differs from that of the mitochondrial genome, and a number of the RNAs contain so many non-encoded nucleotides that their genes escaped identification for years. Previous work has shown that extra nucleotides are added to these RNAs during their synthesis and that the specificity of editing depends on template elements that flank editing sites; however, the underlying mechanism is still mysterious. This project has two broad aims: the identification of factors that participate in nucleotide insertion and the adaptation of a newly developed mitochondrial transformation system for use in editing studies. The coupling of editing with RNA synthesis by the mitochondrial RNA polymerase inform the approaches to be used to enrich for editing factors, which include affinity selection of active transcription complexes and immuno-affinity purification of the polymerase and associated proteins. Long-term goals for the project include the development of an in vitro system assembled from defined components for use in mechanistic studies and the definition of the specific roles played by both template elements and auxiliary factors. Successful completion of these studies will significantly advance the RNA editing field.

Broader Impacts: In addition to providing insight into RNA editing mechanisms, this project will provide training opportunities at many levels. The principal investigator is a former eighth grade science teacher committed to broadening the participation of under-represented groups in the sciences. She has significant experience mentoring high school women, minority students, and undergraduate students and will continue to participate in the highly successful Scientific Enrichment and Opportunity program for minority high school students and outreach programs geared towards minority undergraduates. The project will engage undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral associate, in various aspects of the research. Undergraduate students will carry out research throughout the academic year, culminating in a capstone research project during their senior year. Graduate students and the postdoctoral associate will learn optimization methods and master state-of-the-art techniques. Graduate students and post-docs will also be encouraged to participate in outreach activities and, when appropriate, participate in mentoring undergraduate students to gain relevant supervisory experience. Opportunities for developing presentation skills will be provided for all laboratory members through participation in lab meetings, student symposia, and regional and international meetings, with active encouragement and coaching by the principle investigator. Research results will be written jointly for dissemination to the larger scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  

The basic flow of gene expression from DNA to RNA to protein is much more complex than originally thought.  Normally, RNA is an exact copy of the DNA from which it is made.  Certain RNAs, however, are changed in highly specific ways via RNA editing.  RNA editing is widespread, but has been most extensively studied in mammals, viruses, plants, flies, worms, and parasites.  Changes in RNA editing patterns have been linked to a number of human diseases, including cancers and neurological disorders.  Sequence changes include changing one base to another, the deletion of encoded nucleotides, and the insertion of additional residues.  Changes within RNA coding regions generally result in the production of altered proteins, affecting protein activity, specificity, and/or regulation.  Although RNA editing has been found in many species, only Physarum polycephalum (Pp) and its closest relatives are known to carry out all three major forms of editing.  These primitive single cell organisms require site-specific changes within virtually all of their mitochondrial RNAs to sustain life.  Previous work has shown that ‘extra’ nucleotides are added during RNA synthesis and that the specificity of editing depends on template elements surrounding editing sites; however, the underlying mechanism is still mysterious.  The experiments supported by this grant had two aims: i) the identification of candidate factors that potentially participate in nucleotide insertion and ii) the adaptation of a newly developed mitochondrial transformation system for use in editing studies.  A novel enrichment strategy for editing-competent complexes was devised to reduce the number of potential editing factors to a short list of candidates.  The possible involvement of these affinity-selected proteins will now be investigated individually.  In addition, likely candidates for proteins required for the other two forms of editing in Pp were identified using bioinformatics analyses.   It was also demonstrated that mitochondria transformed via electroporation retain significant editing activity, a finding that opens the door to a range of experiments into editing mechanisms.  Long-term goals for the project include the development of an in vitro system assembled from defined components for detailed mechanistic studies and the definition of the specific roles played by both template elements and auxiliary factors. 

Broader Impacts:   

Integration of research and education:  This grant provided training/professional development opportunities at many levels.  Research opportunities were provided for a Ph.D. student, 3 undergraduate students, 2 community college students, 2 high school students, and a high school science teacher, five from demographic groups underrepresented in the sciences.  Students mastered a diverse array of laboratory techniques, acquiring experience in the design, implementation, documentation, and interpretation of experiments.  Students developed presentation skills through participation in lab meetings, symposia, and regional/international meetings.  Writing proficiency was cultivated through the preparation of capstone research reports, thesis committee summaries, and jointly written articles for dissemination to the larger scientific community.  Participation in an outreach project in the Cleveland Public Schools led to the establishment of a collaboration with a local high school science teacher.  She and two of her students spent three weeks in the laboratory learning basic cell culture and molecular biology techniques, training to use equipment that had been donated to the school, and carrying out experiments.  Laboratory exercises developed during this time are now being used in multiple high school classes.  The primary goal of this ongoing collaboration is to engage underrepresented minority students in STEM activities to encourage them to consider careers in science.
